I'm kind of a picky eater when it comes to creature treats, but I will try anything from the ocean at least once. With such a tiny place and a no reservations policy, I knew coming at peak time on a weekend night was going to be a bit of a challenge. This was not an incorrect assumption. We considered scrapping the whole idea but some time spent at Goody G's took the edge off. We ended up waiting an hour and a half, which was exactly what we were told. We were finally seated by a little half cherub, half merbaby statue perched behind our seats who eyed our every movement with his languid, frozen gaze. The table arrangements here are not for those that long for privacy, you will no doubt get dragged into conversation by those around you. Just (lobster) roll with it. After our adult beverages were procured, we launched into our appetizer and raw bar orders. I got the Japanese octopus salad and the rest of the table got a nice sampling of oysters. I enjoyed my salad, though it didn't quite have the wow factor I thought it would. The little bit of citrus flavor that I did get was divine, just need to pump up the volume. Being the incredibly individualistic persons that we are, everyone got the hot lobster roll for our main course. Okay.Can I say, when you're about 2 prosecco glasses deep on a humid summer night a hot roll of rich meat is maybe not the best idea? Despite the awkwardness of eating such a thing in such conditions, it was really pretty good. Very buttery, if I go back and order again I may ask to go easy on it next time. The bread was good, and the portion was massive. And the fries. Oof. I can't even explain how good they were. We did not have to wait long for anything, service was swift but a little barebones. Kind of expected a bit more out of the place in that department.While it wasn't the religious experience some people like to rave about, I would definitely pay a visit again. Cherub-merbaby needs love.

Reviews.Author: Johnna M.
Reviews.Content: I'm reluctant to review because really how many more compliments can I give Neptune than the 792 reviewers to come before me. But you know what? Some things are just awesome and deserving of endless, repetitive praise. Like that Adele song. Every man, woman, child and baby feels the need to comment on how much they enjoy "Rolling in the Deep" like every single day and it never really gets old. It IS an excellent song, so keep doing what you're doing. This is how I feel about Neptune Oyster. It is an excellent place, so keep doing what you're doing, and we'll keep raving. I, too, was reluctant to visit due to tales of an endless wait and I, too, now understand that the wait is certainly worth it and the host suggesting fun places to kill time before made it that much better. I, too, am impressed with the cozy little atmosphere and enjoyed our bar side seats. I, too, found the white wine list impressive and perfect for accompanying seafood and I, too, enjoyed the tuna tartar appetizer finding the avocado a perfect accompaniment and maybe even ate aioli with a smile (never bring that up again. I mean it.) I, too, realize all the previous statements don't matter because we came for the oysters and they were indeed, fresh, varied, and wonderful. So Mother Teresa was a nice woman, The Godfather is a good movie, and Neptune Oyster is a great restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Jill F.
Reviews.Content: I did this Neptune right. Neptune did me right. I want some more Neptune in my life right now.Basically, I went at 5:30, gave my phone number and name with the goal to be seated before 8 p.m. Good Start, Good Idea. After being told 2 hours...I waited at a nearby bar, drank one glass of wine and waited for my Father from out of town to come later. (good idea if you have company to go before them)  We were seated at 7:45 after an arduous wait outside, drooling at the little man in the window shucking oysters. We chatted it up with tourists, it was totally cute and added to the experience.And then we were seated, obviously closely to the group next to us. Which was quite fun because they were all foodies and totally excited to be there as well. It was such a family little experience I loved sitting nearby people. It was charming, not annoying. Did I mention our HILARIOUS and freaking awesome waiter?! So cool. He had a fun nickname too....I forget what is was, he was fast, sharp, funny and engaging. I started off with five different oysters. All fresh and delicious. All East Coast ones, they came out quickly after ordering. We thought it was bad karma to not order two hot, buttered, dripping with pleasure-inducing sensation, lobster rolls. So we did. And my mouth is drooling onto my computer as we speak, remembering it's toasty, lump, plump lobstery, buttery, briochy goodness. It's 25 dollars. It's a food orgasm. Who is complaining?! Also, the fries were delish, crisp and bomb. Very good to hold up to the quality of the roll. My father also tried a bowl of the clam chowder, which was in a thin broth (not thick and chunk) with tons of plump little clams floating around and fresh veggies that were still magically al dente, but divine  and all topped with a fresh crack of pepper to add some real pep. We saw tons of delicious fish and clams and oysters and tuna and tartare all come out during our magical, foodgasm family experience at Neptune...and I must say. I want to go back. Do it right. Get it tonight and get you're Neptune going.

Reviews.Author: Shaina P.
Reviews.Content: mmmm.... mmmmMMMM .... MMMMMM !!!!Several orgasmic food things can be found on Neptune's menu, including (explanations below): + Clam Chowder                          11.00 + Oysters                                        2.30 to 2.80 ea + Sweet Potato Puree                  part of a 31.00 entree + Warm Buttered Lobster Roll   25.00CLAM CHOWDERMilky, not over-creamed, clean crisp taste if you ever thought that was possible of a chowder, definitely not your traditional version, but had all the classic ingredients (clam chunks, potatoes, cream).  Something about the underlying flavor of this dish ROCKED my world.  Perhaps an extra concentrated lobster broth?  Salsify?  What is it??OYSTERSFlying Point, ME - HUGE shell, big and meaty with an earthy mushroom finish; Pemaquid, ME - medium in size with a citrus finish (definitely accurately described by Neptune staff); Sunnyside, PEI - medium in size, mild flavor with a rush of sake at the end (boo-yah!).  My fave was definitely Flying Point.  In my mind, the bigger the better!  And at $2.3 ea, it was a great deal, too!  Pricing the individual oyster is the way to go.  Neptune is king at that.SWEET POTATO PUREEThis special item came with Saturday's special of pork 'n clams.  It was prepared this time with two thick pork chops served over a dollop of the puree and all of this topped with fried clams and julienned apple slaw.  This whole dish was divine, might I add, but the puree was something to behold.  Sweet potato, you think, sweet.  But not this time.  It's sweet was cut with some mystery savory thing and it was light and umami-licious!  A bowl of that stuff aside my lobster roll would put me over the edge!  Speaking of which ...WARM BUTTERED LOBSTER ROLLIf you love lobster, you must get this dish!  Don't be swayed to trying other thingers, because this dish will get your libido rolling!  It's not an impressive size but when has size mattered in life...?  *shrug*  The warm version must be opted for over cold, since, where else can you get a warm lobster roll except in CT??  It's served with thick cut fries (hardly worthwhile).  Ah, but the meat of the lobster is nice and cut into mouthful sized pieces where you can tell which piece is from the tail, knuckle, and claw.  It's drizzled with warm butter which soaks right into the roll.  And all together: salt, butter, meat, and soft roll with a slight char ... WOW I was in heaven!  I consider myself a picky lobster eater but I will return over and over for this treasure.Other things to consider: + The restaurant is small.  The bar is reserved for diners not waiters.  Expect to wait.  There are no reservations. + Some of the other entree options weren't up to par with the flavors of the dishes described above.   + The Vitello Tonnato was bland and difficult to eat.   + The mussels, though very well prepared, were over-dilled.  I'd say stick with the fronds and root, but forget about the seeds. + The salmon was unimpressive in size and cooked quality.  Perhaps slightly over-cooked. + TRY the special for the night.  This isn't your restaurants leftovers.  Think: fresh catch/in season.I SHALL RETURNAll in all, I can't wait to return to try all of the offerings and/or gorge myself in beautifully shucked oysters all day and paired with a Whale's Tale or Geary's Pale Ale.

Reviews.Author: Jenn C.
Reviews.Content: Neptune is small, and the service can be sort of cold, but as soon as you eat the food I assure you that you won't even remember that the waitress barely looked at you while you made your order.I came here with 3 of my favorite dining companions for a birthday lunch and we ordered the following:Fried Ipswich clams - after a long drive and the long wait we were desperate for food. The fried clams, we were told, were the fastest thing to come out AND a specialty. So when they came out, we attacked and they were amazing - crisp, tender, with the best tartar sauce ever.Burrata - I have to have burrata if I see it on a menu. Neptunes version came on toast, with roasted peppers. It was creamy and smooth on top of the crunchy , garlicky toast point. Artichoke salad - tangy and refreshing, with white anchovies adding a salty pungency. Kind of a grown up Ceasar,light and springy.New England Clam chowder - this was the biggest letdown. It was too thin, and too sweet, without any discernible clams. Skip it and eat something else. Oysters - In my food haze, I forgot to take notice of the ones we got, but they were all briny and very fresh. The waitress recommended some, so if the selection seems overwhelming, just ask and they will help.Hot buttered lobster rolls - this sandwich is as sexy as it sounds. Sweet, meaty chunks of lobster (claw AND tail) in lots of butter, all enclosed in a buttery, toasty roll. Served with a mountain of crisp tender, perfectly salty fries. The sandwich is huge and chock full of the lobster and butter goodness, so you can share it with a friend and still be satisfied. I left full and satisfied and dreaming of buttery lobster even now. Totally worth the long ass drive and the long ass wait.

Reviews.Author: Sarina W.
Reviews.Content: THE VERY BEST PLACE FOR LOBSTER ROLL!!!I cannot stress this enough. I had Lobster Roll in NYC and Martha's Vineyard and nothing compares to the Lobster Roll here. It's the best Lobster Roll I've ever had!!!For $25 you get a very hearty Lobster Roll filled with butter goodness! Place is small so try and come at an off time so you don't get stuck waiting forever. But it's worth the wait!I loved this place and would come back to Boston for this amazing Lobster Roll! So big, so buttery, so delicious!!!

Reviews.Author: Kendra E.
Reviews.Content: To experience the best of Boston, you have to go to Neptune Oyster. I ordered a scallop dish which was amazingly delicious and well worth my $25. I lalalaloved my food! It was seasoned perfectly and cooked right. I'm a big seafood lover but I am not fond of oysters and clams. However, as they say in the UK, "Fear Of Missing Out"... I decided to order two oysters. It was the best FOMO decision I ever made :)The atmosphere, service, and food were great. My friends from out of town loved it too!! So overall, it was worth the wait and money.Tips:** come early to reserve your seat. It takes about two hours before you get seated. **expect to spend a lot for awesome food. If you're a poor college student like me then expect to use your loan money at this fancy schmancy place**with that being said, no need to dress fancy. You can dress casually while enjoying an oyster or two.**must try the lobster roll and cod!!!

Reviews.Author: Debra L.
Reviews.Content: I've been waiting 4 days to write this review hoping I might think of something clever to say but alas, I got nothing. This was the 6th or 7th time I've been to Neptune and by far my least favorite. I was even there with my best friend from junior high who moved away and was back for a visit for this one night only, and it was still only okay. We didn't even have to wait for a table and it was still only okay. We split the Neptune shellfish platter among 4 of us and it was really good. Lots of stuff on it (lobster, crab, shrimp, mussels, littlenecks & oysters). But, there weren't that many oysters & the boys ate them up right quick, so I didn't even get to have one. For my meal I had the tuna ribbons Crudo, which I know I have had before and loved. It was having an off-night last week. I do not remember them using a creamy dressing on it before? I hate creamy dressings and I really hate them with seafood. I didn't think Aioli was supposed to be creamy? Anyway, the wine was good. But there was a line of people waiting for tables and our waiter sort of gave us the heave-ho so I had to suck down my 3/4 full glass in one sip. All in all, I think it was just a case of my ordering wrong but after this night at Neptune I didn't leave with that dreamy "I heart Neptune" feeling that I usually get.

Reviews.Author: Christopher M.
Reviews.Content: I understand that you're a busy, popular restaurant. I understand it was 7:30 at night.  I even understand that there may have been a long wait for a table and I might not have gotten seated that night.  But there is NO excuse for leaving a patron standing in your doorway, completely ignored, for over 25 minutes!Come greet me.  Offer to put my name on a wait list.  Tell me I might not get a table.  Tell me there's a long wait, and the bar is first come, first serve.  Tell me something!  But don't just ignore me and hope I go away.While we did eventually snag a pair of seats at the bar, we never did talk to a hostess or see a wait list, nor did the people who had been standing behind us (they ultimately left in frustration).Once you get a seat, I will admit that Neptune's raw bar is one of the best in the city.  It's quite extensive (albeit expensive), and everything is very, very fresh.  They also have an impressive wine list.However, service does not improve once you're sitting down.  We ordered appetizers and waited about 45 minutes for them.Once they arrived I was also disappointed with the food.  The clam chowder looked wonderful from a distance, but once it hit my spoon I realized it was thin, watery and short on both clams and flavor.I'll grant you that the P.E.I. Mussels Caprese was AMAZING, and I'll highly recommended.I thought the wait for the appetizers was bad, but our food didn't show up for just short of TWO HOURS.  In fact, the three couples surrounding us at the bar all ordered after we did, and they had received and finished their food before we ever received ours (the gal next to me offered me some of her Lobster Spaghettini, probably because my stomach was grumbling so much it shook the bar).I came to Neptune for dinner that night because I wanted a lobster roll, and I heard theirs was the best around.  Conclusion: they're horribly overrated.  The bread came out burnt (literally, the bottom was black) and nearly impossible to eat.  And when I went at the lobster with a fork, I found it was dry and tasted old and slightly sour.And when I was asked, "how is it?" and I told them, the bartenders response was, "Oh," and she walked away.  Well, if you don't care how crappy the food is, don't ask.In the end it was a painfully disappointing and expensive night.  I may go back to Neptune for the raw bar, but I'm probably done with dinners there.

Reviews.Author: Mary T.
Reviews.Content: Good things come in small packages (that's what she said!) I decided to cap off a week of good eating with lunch at Neptune Oyster. While tiny, Neptune is a cute space; subway tiles, a large mirrored menu, small tables, and a long wood bar. It reminds me of a Pottery Barn spread; you know the one where you wish you had enough money to replicate it, even the details and accents they're not hawking. It's not ideal for a groups of more than 4, I think there are only 6-8 tables in all. Also, I'm not sure I'd call this a great date place or at least a romantic one, at lunchtime it got quite loud. I don't mind dining solo, but this time I regretted it...a little. On the one hand, this place isn't much bigger than a postage stamp and flying solo I was lucky to immediately score a seat at the bar. On the other hand, there were so many menu items I wanted to try but only so much room in my stomach. After perusing the menu and drooling over the plates of those sitting next to me, I decided on the cold lobster roll. I had only tried a lobster roll once before, it was served at my conference and had an 80/20 bread-to-lobster ratio - meh. Neptune's lobster roll puts that one to shame. The roll was light and airy, and seemingly dusted with melted butter. The lobster was teeming from the bun; huge hunks of fresh, delicious lobster; writing about it is making me salivate. Hand cut fries accompanied the roll, those were excellent too; perfectly salty and greasy, a nice accompaniment to the roll. I washed it all down with a Whale's Tale Pale Ale, my only misstep; it was recommended by my server, but I wasn't really a fan. Service started out a little slow, sandwiched in between two parties at the bar it took a while to get noticed. Once I was, everyone was so attentive and friendly. TIP: Try to stop in for an early lunch on a weekday, the lines don't seem so horrendous.

Reviews.Author: Eric O.
Reviews.Content: Came here for a birthday dinnerOrdered a lobster roll like a winnerGot oysters of courseWhat a tasty forceDoes this glutinous meal make me a sinner?!The best oysters I've had, this ain't no jokeThe lobster roll had a good butter soakDelicious, I say!And didn't have to payThanks for buying Mike, I know you're broke!

Reviews.Author: Rachel R.
Reviews.Content: When the hostess says, "the wait is going to be about (insert relatively infuriating number here) hours" you say, "okay." Do not be alarmed, perplexed, nor perturbed... just give her your name/cell and begin the countdown to the best meal ever. It doesn't matter if she says six hours, you will wait and it will be worth it. Besides, there are plenty of things to buy and see in the North End in the meantime. You could even get coffee and dessert before dinner to kill time (not that anyone would do that, of course). Although, hypothetically speaking, I recommend hitting up Maria's for baba rum, ricotta pie, and a napoleon... I ate at Neptune twice in two days (and hypothetically Maria's) and would have happily gone again if given extra resources and stomach space. I can't recommend one dish more highly than the next, but I can tell you everything I managed to stuff down my gullet while there.1. Hot lobster roll. Everyone around us was eating this dish, and every person licked their buttery plate clean, from the hot, soaked roll, to the huge, steaming, chunks of lobster, to the perfectly crisp heap of fries and ketchup on the side. The quest for 'best lobster roll in Boston' has effectively been terminated. Not to mention, the empowering feeling that accompanies combining a bite of really cheap food (fries) with really expensive food (lobster) is AWESOME. The best of both worlds is an understatement.2. Uni pasta. There is not nearly enough tubetti in the world, so the fact that this dish featured the tiny tubes immediately won my heart (or perhaps stomach). Between the light, savory, creamy sauce, green peas, morels, chewy little pastas, and uni so tender that chewing became superfluous, it only seemed natural that I eat this dish this twice in 24 hours. My one regret is not having it a third time.3. Johnny cakes. This dish was reminiscent of a bagel, lox & cream cheese on crack. Replace the bagel with a fluffy, chewy johnnycake topped with a sweet molasses-y glaze, the lox for a mound of trout tartare and black caviar, and the cream cheese for a dollop creme fraiche. The contrast of flavors and textures is pretty unique to this dish, and the sweet and salty ratio was perfect. I was craving it again the next morning (I mean, johnny cakes are breakfast food...)4. Ciopinno - An octopus's dream come true. Juicy lobster, heaps of clams and mussels, prawns with heads in tact, and cubes of silver skinned salmon over saffron rice in a spicy broth. I suppose saffron rice doesn't apply to an octopus's dream come true, but aside from that, this entree was just a melange of perfectly prepared, high quality seafood... and besides, everyone loves sucking the juices out of a prawn head. If you're conflicted about which undersea morsel to consume, the ciopinno lets you have it all.In a nutshell, try anything and everything that appeals to you. You can't go wrong, and you probably just waited 3 hours to get in, so take advantage of it. Neptune is the best of the best... so good, you might find yourself back there the next day.

Reviews.Author: Wenbin X.
Reviews.Content: The best

Reviews.Author: David C.
Reviews.Content: So there's this quaint little place in the North End that specializes in all things seafood. It's called Neptune Oyster Bar--perhaps you've heard of it?You know what? Based on the 983 reviews that have preceded this and the fact that the restaurant was completely full at FOUR O'CLOCK on a Friday, I'm guessing that you have. I'm also guessing there's not much more I can tell you about Neptune that hasn't already been said.When I went, I had the ubiquitous lobster roll, which is pretty much just as amazing as everyone says it is, replete with sweet and tender lobster meat coated in a generous helping of warm butter. I felt pressure to gobble up my roll as fast as I could, however, as the butter compromised the integrity of the bun rather quickly. Despite my best efforts, I eventually had to resort to a fork and knife to finish it. The fries that accompanied the roll were rather unremarkable, but that's really my only complaint.The Neptunes on Piggyback (fried oysters atop a confiture of Berkshire pork and golden raisins) made for an interesting appetizer, both texturally and from a flavor-perspective, but I'm not sure I'd order it again. My roommate and I of course had to try a couple oysters from the raw bar, and while they were good and I appreciated the expansive selection, it was hard to stomach the almost $3 price tag per briny morsel. I think I'll stick to the various $1 oysters specials around the city. The real star of the show was the mignonette, anyway.But that lobster roll, oh my!

Reviews.Author: Dee B.
Reviews.Content: Easily one of the best lunches I've ever had and definitely the best seafood I've had in a city restaurant.  Thanks to Yelp, I knew all about the small but excellent Neptune, and decided to check it out with three friends on a summer Sunday.With the exception of the clam chowder, which was just underwhelming, everything we tried was absolutely fresh and delicious.  We shared the fried clams, which were amazing -- just enough breading to enhance, not hide, the flavors.  Our table also had one cold lobster roll (with no bread), one hot lobster roll, the blue crab salad and an appetizer that contained a jonnycake cornmeal flatbread with some trout and caviar.  I tried bits of everything, and it was all was fantastic -- even the french fries that come with the lobster rolls.Even the pitcher of filtered water that was brought to our table and constantly refilled was perfect!

Reviews.Author: Fred S.
Reviews.Content: Dear owner: your greeter with red hair just lost you a long standing patron. Feel free to reach out if you would like details.Great food (which you serve) does not require great arrogance. I shouldn't have to beg to put my name on a list after asking a qualifying question about wait time.I would suggest taking a lead from Jason Bond @Bondir, who, along with his staff, shows that exceptional food can be served in a humble and respectful manner.If folks want an equally great lobster roll without the scene, go to Alive and Kickin in Cambridge. We'll be taking our business to B&G this afternoon.

Reviews.Author: Diana Y.
Reviews.Content: SO WORTH THE HYPE. Seriously, this was the first and best meal I had in Boston. I'm always a little skeptical of touristy places but man this place is awesome. Few things:1. No reservations and the wait was a little over an hour when I stopped by around 1:30pm on a Saturday. Theres a lot to walk around and they'll just call you on your cell when your table is ready. 2. Oyster lovers: they have a great variety of oysters and it even comes with detailed description of each so you can get an idea before you order. The island creek oyster and katama were the highlights for me. 3. Lobster roll is a MUST ORDER. order it hot with butter. Portion is huge and cheaper than other places. Definitely a huge highlight of my meal4. Clam chowder is good but can be skipped. Tourists, definitely make a pit stop here. Forget the rest.

Reviews.Author: Steph C.
Reviews.Content: When I first went to Neptune Oyster in 2009, I didn't know much about the place. Namely, I didn't know it was so honking popular, and I didn't know it was so honking popular for its lobster rolls.Turns out I still did okay - after a second visit, I can say with confidence that the crown jewel of this New England seafood mecca is the juicy, meaty Neptuneburger.Neptune does not take reservations, and apparently showing up at 7:30 on a Thursday was very naive.  We went to Daily Catch instead and came back before noon the next day.  Had we come any later, we would have met the same fate.Our party of four sat at the counter and managed to dine family style without too much difficulty.  The service was reasonable enough, and the food came out fast.The food was delicious.  We started with oysters and an octopus cocktail.  The oyster menu is expansive and seasonal, and every oyster I've had has been superb.  This time I enjoyed a firm, crisp Kusshi and a larger, briny Wellfleet that had a great sweet finish.  The octopus cocktail was likewise tasty and refreshing, with top notch seafood and clean ceviche flavors.We shared two Maine lobster rolls, the bronzini, and a Neptuneburger.  Neptune is known for the lobster rolls, and we tried both the hot and cold versions, which came with butter and mayo, respectively.  They were $25 each and while they were scrumptious, so was the $13 roll at James Hook.  But that isn't a real complaint - the serving of lobster was generous, and both preparations showed strength in the sheer quality of the meat.  Robed in butter, the hot lobster roll boasts pure, satisfying flavors and a nice meatiness to the huge chunks of lobster.  The mayo on the cold roll was just enough to bind, and though the cold was not equal to the hot, it was quite nice.  One actual gripe is that the rolls were just not exciting.  Even the plain hot dog buns were a missed opportunity (for more butter, mainly).The whole grilled bronzini was a fabulous entree, with a delicate texture to the fish.  It didn't yield to the fork in flakes, but it wasn't mushy, either.  It was served alla cinque terre, with basil pesto, fingerlings, and fennel salad, in a shallow pool of tomato-olive broth.  The flavors were broad and soothing.  But the winner was still the Neptuneburger, that juicy cheddar cheeseburger with fried oysters, garlic mayo, and that irresistible relish.  Forget seafood for a second.  Choose meat.Everything is great, though, and I don't actually recommend forgoing the incredible array of fresh seafood.  Get your lobster roll (hot), and get your burger on top.  And if you want to eat at all, show up early.

Reviews.Author: Elizabeth S.
Reviews.Content: Holy mackerel... and oysters, hot buttered lobster rolls, fresh clams, etc.Now that's good.We started off with a dozen oysters and a half-dozen raw clams. The stars of the raw bar in my opinion were the Kumamoto and the Moon Shoal. I also deeply enjoyed the Summerside. All three types were the perfect amount of briny, plump and sweet. Both the cherrystone and little neck clams were tasty, but we preferred the little necks.For our appetizers, we opted for the clam chowder and the Neptunes on Piggyback. The clam chowder was not the traditional Boston clam chowder we know and love; it was creamier and filled with large, meaty clams, and I enjoyed every bite. The Neptunes on Piggyback were tasty, with fried oysters atop a sort of pork pâté on a crostini, but the part that transformed the fine dish into a delight was the golden raisins.Finally, for the chef d'oeuvre: we've heard the burger is good, and the trout and scallops both looked tasty, but we knew we just couldn't leave without trying the glorified hot butter lobster roll. Best lobster roll in town? Of course. Best lobster roll I've ever had? Definitely. It was pure lobster meat - I was clearly eating the claws and tails, drizzled in hot butter and cradled in a butter and lobster-soaked soft bun.I paired my meal with a Muscadet, and he had a Guinness, as the poster on the wall correctly suggested that the stout is a perfect complement to lobster. Other patrons had cava or bellinis, which both looked refreshing.I found the oyster selection different from but as equally varied as Island Creek Oyster Bar's. ICOB has cheaper Island Creeks, so I'd recommend ordering only the oysters you can't find at ICOB at Neptune's raw bar. Most of Neptune's oysters had pieces of shells in them, which is a miss I've never found at ICOB. So for oysters, ICOB might win. For lobster rolls? Neptune, no contest.Time saver: there was no line as I entered this seafood mecca at 11:30 on a Sunday, and the line didn't start forming until I waddled out about an hour later, so I'd recommend Sunday lunch for anyone hoping to avoid a line.When I return, I'll likely skip the appetizers, double the amount of oysters, and order a lobster roll to share, as this rich treat is possibly best shared between two, assuming you don't merely want to pass out in a food coma after your meal.

Reviews.Author: Irene L.
Reviews.Content: Neptune Oyster is def. one of my fave restaurants in Boston. I came here on a rainy night with my sissy & two friends. Despite the weather, people were still willing to wait outside for ~30-60 minutes.The restaurant itself is really small. There are about 8 tables, cramped together, and a bar area. I am seriously not a fan of seafood but my opinions may have changed because of the awesomeness of the food here. The lobster roll (warm), oysters, and fried clams were exceptional. Nothing gave me the impression that I was eating something straight out of seawater (a main reason i dont enjoy the taste of most seafood lol). My only complaint would be the salad we had. There were chunks of what I think is cured meat, and it was way too salty. If you're in town, Neptune Oyster is a must try indeed.

Reviews.Author: Min T.
Reviews.Content: On our last night in Boston, the gay boyfriend and I intended to have a fancy pants meal. But after several high-end meals, we just wanted something good (cough, cheaper). It had been recommended to me we try Union Oyster House for oysters but then I got the real deal from Ben G. He said we had to try Neptune for the lobster roll. He made it sound so amazing and I couldn't stop thinking about it. He did think one other might be better for oysters (B&G Oysters) but I was chasing the lobster roll dream.I started with four Island Creek oysters ($2.50 an oyster/ $10 total) and then the lobster roll ($25). Did I say something about this not being a fancy pants meal? Yeah, well, it was definitely getting there.Heck, the fish tacos here are $23! Pretty outrageous. Of course, once I got there, I was highly attracted to the idea of the sturgeon with lentils but no, I couldn't leave without that lobster roll. The gay boyfriend had the burger with relish on the side. He also ordered the clam chowder ($11) which took a bit of time but it's made to order.I loved my oysters and really thought about trying more out but since the server said the Island Creeks were her fave, I was momentarily satisfied with a spoonful of the clam chowder which was definitely awesome. Loved the fresh herbs in it.Then our food came. I could not believe how much lobster there was! I got it poached in butter and not mayo. Either way, it probably was a heart attack on a plate. The fries were good too. But after a while, I wanted something different. Maybe a crunch? I ended up eating the gay boyfriend's relish as I was eating the lobster roll.I had a bite of the burger and it was decadent. It was just a great burger and enormous. Well worth the $14 (well, maybe not worth $14 but it was definitely a good value). We left very happy we beat the rush and on such a good food note.

Reviews.Author: David R.
Reviews.Content: This place was perfect for the occasion.  We wanted classic, upscale New England seafood in a charming, romantic setting.  Done!  We had been frightened by tales of a long wait, but there were only three other tables occupied when we arrived.  Of course, they only have about eight tables plus the counter, but it was the perfect balance of quiet and cozy with warm and alive.  (This was a cold Sunday evening around 7 pm.)Neither my girlfriend nor I much care for oysters, so we forsook the raw bar in favor of early courses.  She got the famous chowder, and I tried the lobster salad with baby iceberg wedge, grape tomatoes, stilton crumble, crispy pancetta bits, and tarragon vinaigrette.  It felt simply off somehow, as if one ingredient was seriously amiss but the rest all worked together in wonderful symphony.  It may have been either the tarragon or the lobster meat itself.  I tasted the chowder but failed to appreciate the heaps of praise that I had read.  It was rather bland, actually.  We would have liked to have bread or rolls with the salad and soup, but none were offered.Thankfully, the quality of the meal picked up from there.  I ordered one of the daily specials--the Gloucester fisherman's plate, a monstrous assembly of cod, scallops, swordfish, and various shellfish over potatoes and cabbage, with a savory, slightly creamy broth.  Very, very good, especially the cod and scallops.  My girlfriend wanted to eat lighter and ordered the scallops.  Those were some of the best that I've ever tasted.No coffee or dessert at this restaurant:  there are plenty of great bakeries in the neighborhood, and Neptune Oyster knows its niche.  It's a classy but unpretentious, seemingly family-run, establishment.  While we were there, several regulars came in; someone's daughter was sitting at the counter coloring; all that merely contributed to the friendly vibe and did not detract from the upscale warmth.  They open at 11:30 every day and would probably be great for a business lunch.

Reviews.Author: Jia J.
Reviews.Content: "Aw, Neptune Oysters ALL THE WAY. Here, I'll show you where it is..."So emphatic was the rotund Faneuil Hall pub bouncer about  the quality of the lobster rolls at Neptune that he'd personally escorted us - cig still burning in hand - all the way to the edge of the throughway that faces off with the North End. He pointed out the entrance to Salem Street, the infamous culinary artery of the best Little Italy in the world. We started towards it."GO...THEY TASTE LIKE A PAIR OF DOUBLE Ds!!!" he shouted after us. With this echoing endorsement, we went from walking to running towards the establishment despite the comment's general vulgarity and logical strangeness (just think of an analogical statement for a heterosexual female to make, and in reference to a lobster roll?!).The compact ground floor space was lit up by soft-hued electric lights to evoke a grotto - an aesthetic standout in the midst of the more traditional decor of neighboring pasta and canoli houses. The paneled ceiling was like a giant bar of white chocolate, raised with ornate and antique patterns.Sadly, the cozy scale inside (15-seat bar, 27-seat banquette) meant that there was no space at the inn for us. There were three of us and only two empty stools at the shiny bar, so my resourceful girlfriend located another stool in the back and dragged it forth. She was stopped by a server, who told her she couldn't just move furniture around as she pleased, and that even the bar spots were earmarked for the arrival of others. (On a President's Day Monday night at 8:30 p.m. at a no-reservations place?)This resulted in my friend shrilling about the elitist bullshit of the place and the bitchiness of "that elitist bitch," so her man and I quietly ushered her into Rabia's down the block. There, we sat deliberating over the strange lobster roll variations (involving toppings of bleu cheese and onion) and grumbling about the $24.95 price until the server covering the empty floor chirped that they were clear out of lobster rolls anyhow.Back to Neptune we went. This time, there were three seats at the bar. We asked a different server if it was okay to sit, and suddenly it was. Ordering was easy because it was only a matter of choosing between butter and mayonnaise dressings. Here, the price was $25 even. For someone who grew up in New England and has therefore scored plenty of snapping-fresh rolls in many points North for less than half the price, a QUARTER OF A HUNDRED BONES was a tough fare to choke down. But I did it anyway, recalling the bouncer's enthusiastic advertisement.Our rolls arrived quickly. A fair portion of butter-drizzled claw and tail meat - slightly too well done for my taste - was embedded in a fluffy but otherwise non-remarkable bun. It was good, but not arousingly so. After all, it's a G.D. LOBSTER ROLL.Between our hard won (or bought) mouthfuls, we stared up at a chalkboard displaying an impressive variety of local and Pacific oysters with prices like 2 9/10...per shell. Still, my NYC price goggles easily had me considering a couple Kumamotos from Washington but I decided to save my dizzough for when I'm actually out in the Pacific Northwest.We asked for the check, got it, and paid up. My card was charged twice, so we called the server back. She wasn't particularly apologetic and seemed more hassled, but promised that she'd fix the problem and that I wouldn't see two charges on my account. "Good, or else I'll be making a phone call," I said obnoxiously, breaking into laughter with my friends...because what would a night in an Italian neighborhood in Boston be without empty threats? She turned around with a look on her face like she wished she could scratch my eyes out. Anyway, the moral of the story seems to be: If you want lobster rolls, go to Woodman's in Essex MA or to Jack's in Hampton Beach, NH or some shack in Maine (not NYC, which skimp on me no matter what) or anywhere in between. Or go to any Market Basket between Mass. and Maine in season, get some steamed ones and make your own. If you want seafood in Beantown, don't be above going to an Irish pub near Faneuil ($13-$15) or to Legal Seafoods (standard MP). If you want special oysters, get closer to their beds, or hit up B&G for a more focused hunt.If you want crowded old world nooks with alternately sassy or warm service from young girls or grandmas, THEN come to the North End, but note that pasta or pastries will provide a cheaper and more congruous experience.In Neptune-land, a placid (i.e. NOT my girlfriend) out of towner might be wowed, and a gastro-snob with a bankroll to burn on accompaniments of fine wine without crying (reportedly: Bennifer Affleck, Flea, The Edge, Leo, Kelly Clarkson, JT) might be deliberately under radar. But the real intersection between Boston and Seafood  is something more underplayed and underpriced, especially when you're talking about chopped chunks of crustacean in a glorified hot dog bun.

Reviews.Author: tom k.
Reviews.Content: Let's shuck the sh*t and get to the pearl of wisdom: next time I'd skip the entrees, the only *meh* thing about this place.Most importantly the oysters and raw bar were perfect, and we had great service.  The recommended wines were a-flowin and complemented the food.  The lively bistro ambiance surely set a joyous mood, and all was happy ... but the entrees just didn't present a value to me.  I found them overpriced, conservative portions of standard seafood fare.  They just didn't blow me outta the watah ...Next time, I'm gonna stick to the raw bar, appetizers, and drinks ... and I'll be one happy duck.

Reviews.Author: David C.
Reviews.Content: Overall, while the food was decent, it was at least 90 degrees inside without functioning air conditioning.  It is also very cramped.  I had the warm lobster role with butter.  Was very good.  Lots of lobster and a nice soft bun.  French fries were greasy and soggy.  Wife had cioppino.  There was a lot of seafood but was pretty bland.  PEI mussels and oysters were both good. Price with tip was approx $130. Overall, couldn't really enjoy the food due to the extreme heat.  Not a great value.  However food was decent.

Reviews.Author: Michelle T.
Reviews.Content: There really isn't that much more to say than has already been said. But seriously the goods:Lobster roll with hot butter $25 (about 2-3 lbs of lobster meat in a hot buttery roll and comes with fries)Kumomoto Oysters: small delicious and only $2.90 (other places charged up to $4 a popVeal and Tuna Tartare Sandwich $19: sounds unconventional but the flavors worked together to create a harmonious surf and turf sandwich. suprisingly refreshing. comes with fries.Mussels with apples and foie: $14 (SERIOUSLY, right??) Steamed mussels with apples, herbs, and foie melted on the top to create a rich and sinfully delectable broth.Grilled Octopus "Fra Diavlo" Fra diavlo is a spicy red sauce. the grilled baby octopus was perfectly cooked, not too chewy, and you could still taste the ocotpus over a bed of soft polenta and the fra divalo sauce $14Artic Char Crudo: seemingly unusual combination, but worked perfect all together. Came with pickled beets over creme fraiche and sprinkled with pastrami seasonings. yum! $11Sea Urchin: they open and serve the sea urchin in the shell. Probably the freshest sea urchin and tastiest too! $5Add a few pints of Harpoon IPA.This place rocks. done and done.

Reviews.Author: Melissa B.
Reviews.Content: You know what I like to do in the summer? Sit on my ass all day at Crane Beach and then go to Neptune Oyster, to do some more sitting, this time at the bar and order a bunch of Oysters and a glass of prosecco. The restaurant is very cozy and can get packed, so be patient if you have to wait for a seat. It's def worth it.Beware- you may end up also ordering a lobster roll...

Reviews.Author: Christina C.
Reviews.Content: Great Oysters.  Great Wine. One heck of a wait!6pm on a saturday night, not hungry yet? put your name down on the list. 6:30pm on a saturday night, not hungry yet? put your name down on the list. 7pm on a saturday night, not hungry yet? put your name down on the list.Yeah, just put your name down on the list and come back later. They don't take reservations - its first come first serve for both tables and bar seating. Average wait time is at least 1 hr for parties of 2-4. They'll take your name and number and give you a call when your table is ready. The place is pretty small and gets packed really quick and the waiting list can get quite long.They had a nice selection of both east coast and west coast oysters. Katama bay was definitely my fav, followed by Waianno and Taylor Bay. You can choose either the cocktail sauce or the other (green) one when ordering the oysters. They were ok, I like it better with just lemon and tabasco. I also got the fried Ipswitch clams which I was told was a very Boston thing to eat. They were ok. Too chewy and fried for my tastes.I'll come back again the next time I'm in town and stick to the oysters and perhaps try to lobster roll.And yes, just as others say- it is worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Calli C.
Reviews.Content: To celebrate my boyfriend's completion of a quarter-century, I took him to the one place that I, with a bivalve allergy, would never think of going - Neptune Oyster. Thankfully, they had a menu of fantastic dishes that do not involve the evil critters, so I was able to find something to my liking while Pete indulged in oyster bliss. We went around 7 PM on a very very cold and rainy Sunday, and we were happily surprised that as soon as we walked in there were a few seats at the bar and at a table available.What made this a five-star experience was the service. I felt like the server truly wanted to make sure we had a great time, and when I told him about my allergy, he patted my shoulder and assured me that he would take care of it personally. We asked for recommendations on everything, and he was not afraid to speak up about his personal faves and suggestions. So on his word, we had a few glasses of white wine and started off with the smoked tuna johnnycake. Wow. It tasted a bit like a fancy bagel with lox, but it was so much more complex than that - the salty fish with the sweetness of the cake was a great combination. I could eat it for days!For entrees, Pete had a dozen oysters, all on the recommendation of our amazing server (I wish I had gotten his name! He is such a nice person!!), and I had to get the lobster roll, just to find out what everyone has been raving out. When it came out, it became immediately apparent. The amount of lobster is impressive, all drenched in clarified butter to the point that I had difficulty picking up the roll it came on. I didn't think it was possible for fries to be refreshing, but next to that pile of what probably amounted to several sticks of butter, they were. I'm honestly still not a fan of lobster in itself, but this has got to be the best lobster dish I've ever had.My only recommendation would be to serve dessert!! Get some gelato or some pastries from somewhere in the North End - that would have been the icing on the cake.

Reviews.Author: Blair H.
Reviews.Content: Neptune is approximately 11 AU from Uranus.The Lobsta Roll is also out of this world...zing...

Reviews.Author: Maggie W.
Reviews.Content: I have never been SOOOO sick!  I had a horrible case of food poisoning after eating here.  I had the crab meat salad and the scallops.  However, I just tasted the scallops (they had a liquorice taste which I did not like and were not cooked through) and switched with my boyfriend who had fish - so, it had to be the crab because the fish was cooked through.  I was sick within an hour of eating and sick throughout the night.  I enjoyed the atmosphere, and we had a really nice waiter - but I would not eat there again after the agony that followed.  Also, terrible parking situation, which is normal in the North End.I REALLY wanted to like this place - but in the end, I was too sick to ever go back.

Reviews.Author: Mark T.
Reviews.Content: It was latish for a weeknight, 10:25, when we went in. Yelp said they were open until 11 so we thought we would be able to get a meal."Are you still open for dinner?""No, sorry the kitchen closed at 9:30."Which would all be good except for the fact that they advertise as being open until 11.Moral to the story: don't lie about how late you stay open or you'll get a bad yelp review.

Reviews.Author: Vincent C.
Reviews.Content: Pretty disappointed by my experience here. Given how people have been raving about the food here, I had pretty high expectations. It was an interested dining experience overall. We got there around 5:45pm, put our name on the list and they called us back after about half an hour. Not bad of a wait by any means. The place was tiny, very cramped. I felt like I was sitting on top of the people at the table to my right. It was also HOT; on an already hot day outside, it was not any better inside the restaurant. As for the food, I will start off with the one positive: oysters were delicious and fresh. The rest of the food experience was very subpar in my opinion. I ordered clam chowder. The chowder was watery, almost to the texture of milk. The potatoes in our chowder was very undercooked to the point that they seemed raw. It was nice that there was a good amount of sizeable clams, but disappointing overall. The hot lobster roll was even more of a disappointment. Not sure what everyone else loves about it. I can make the same thing at home and it would cost much less than $25+. It was literally just steamed lobster meat drenched in butter stuffed in a hot dog bun also drenched in butter. There was no twist or any kind of kick that made it stand out. The fries that come with the lobster roll were overly salty as well. I have to say that this was one of the most disappointing meals I have had in a while and will not go back to Neptune. If you read most of my other reviews, I'm typically pretty generous and enjoy the majority of restaurants I try, so this negative review is saying a lot. Of course this is relative to expectations, but simply given the astronomical prices for subpar food, I would never in my life suggest anyone go for a meal at this restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Stuart D.
Reviews.Content: Dateline Boston October 2012.  I sensed that a trip to the area would not be complete without finding a decent batch of raw oysters to consume.  While partaking in bantering with business associates in Seaport, I decided that a little intel gathering here would go a long way toward success.  Neptune... Neptune... Neptune.  That's all I got.  Was there no other choice?  While heading back into my hotel in the North End, a quick conversation with the doorman confirmed everything... Neptune.I got there as early as I could which meant about 6:00 and for a party of one, a twenty minute wait was nothing (though by the time I left, a party of four would have to wait two hours!).  The place is quite small, but well worth any wait.  I left my cell phone number and ventured around and magically enough, the rang me up when things were ready to go.It can be as daunting as ordering wine or sushi when presented with a list of oysters with different merroir.  I went with simplistic descriptions such as buttery, briny, and champagne which landed me with Moon shoal, Tatamagouche, and Beausoleil respectively.  Fantastic.  Fresh and clean.  It was just the quality and presentation that I was looking for.  I followed that up with a recommendation from the afore-mentioned doorman which was the Neptune Burger.  It was a complete pleasure in and of itself with carefully prepared fried oysters and properly cooked burger.  Even though it's an oyster place - I would highly suggest it.My advice.... put your name on the list and simply be prepared to walk around the block... check into a bakery or something... make it a real experience... enjoy life!

Reviews.Author: Nate Y.
Reviews.Content: I came for what else but the lobster roll, but my first attempt was foiled since they ran out of lobster by 8PM *sad face*My second attempt was at 4PM, so no waiting, and plenty of lobster, although when I called  to make sure they had lobster the woman professed "we never run out", hmmmmmmmm.Anywho, we started with some choice oysters, which for me who can take it or leave it, I definitely enjoyed partaking in it. I especially enjoyed the variety from RI, as recommended by our server. We get to the main attraction, lobster roll. The lobster meat was plentiful and cooked right, as was the butter that was already added to it. What I found that separates it from other lesser forms of this sea faring treat was the roll. The roll was not the typical hot dog roll from the clam shack, nor was it your atypical white bread sub roll. It seemed to be a delicious brioche-type roll that enhanced the butter flavors for the lobster, mmmmmmm.I've kept off one star to see if I can find a lobster roll than can top this. We shall see....

Reviews.Author: Sereia C.
Reviews.Content: Ways to describe the finish of different oysters, as per Neptune Oyster's menu...melon...mushroom...buttered popcorn...Tried them all.  Very good, but I'm pretty sure the aftertaste was, well, oyster.Cozy little place.  And by cozy, I mean, shoulder to shoulder with the person sitting next to you at a different table.  We decided not to sit at the table they were about to seat us at, and just grab some oysters and a drink at the bar, then go somewhere else for dinner.  Really though, loved the oysters, and the crab claws at the raw bar were absolutely a-m-a-z-i-n-g.  I would definitely go back at off-peak hours when it wasn't so crowded to check out more of the menu-

Reviews.Author: grace y.
Reviews.Content: Not sure I can say anything that hasn't been said already but I want to give my 2 cents anyway.I visited Boston this past weekend and I did pretty much all the touristy stuff suggested by my friends. Pretty hit or miss. This place definitely did the trick and left my stomach oh so happy. If there is a 1 hour wait, leave your phone number with them, and just wait. It's totally worth it.My boyfriend and I had the following dishes:- A selection of oysters: I don't remember what they were but they were incredibly fresh and delicious. Order both sauces. It makes it that much more exciting!- yellow fin ceviche: I've had ceviche a bunch of times but this version was buttery with avocado and rich tuna as opposed to citrus. Bomb! - PEI mussels: The broth with these mussels was so delicious I literally wanted to chug the remaining broth like soup. I tried to keep it classy and fake the funk by using my mussel shell as a little spoon. We ended up asking the waitress if we could keep the broth to eat with our lobster roll and she was so sweet she offered us bread. The bread was even grilled. Super bonus points!- Lobster roll (duh!): Thank god I don't have cholesterol problems because if I had to choose between this lobster roll and my health, lobster roll wins. We got the lobster roll, hot w/ butter, and it was to die for. It's pretty pricey, but honestly, it's an entire lobster on the bun. Even the fries accompanying the lobster roll was delicious and crisp (I think they were hand-made). Nothing about this dining experience could have been better, honestly (minus the wait). I don't dish out a lot of 5 *s but this place seriously deserves it. As soon as we walked out the door, my boyfriend says to me "that was one of the best meals i've had". Go visit Neptune Oyster ftw!

Reviews.Author: Christina S.
Reviews.Content: Best hot lobster roll ever. Getting a table takes forever, but I don't really care because the hot lobster roll is the best. Did I say it's delicious? Cause it is, lol. The roll itself is good, but when you add in pure buttered lobster between those buns, it's so decadent. Every time I visit Boston, Neptune is my reward after a 5 1/2 hour flight :) I guess I should add that their fries are really yummy too.

Reviews.Author: Katherine I.
Reviews.Content: Father of the Ocean, does Nace know Neptune personally?  Every oyster has always been as fresh as cold, sea air on an early, winter morning and as if Neptune himself selected each mollusk.  The mollusks are divine along with everything else on the menu - except their lobster roll bread.  Curse words couldn't express my genuine appreciation and respect for their culinary accomplishments.                                                                                                                         Eat Love Here!

Reviews.Author: luke b.
Reviews.Content: If Jesus, Daddy and the Spook ate lobster rolls... here's where they'd go.  Let me tell you all about the deliciousness: First oysters.  SO GOOD!  Like eating the delicious parts of the ocean in one salty, meaty gulp.  *drool*Next, the lobster roll.  Served hot (with butter) or cold (with mayo).  Jeff... not me... got the hot one, for some reason i was stupid and got the salmon which was amazing but it was NOT the lobster roll.  This thing is amazing.  So lobstery, so buttery soooo lobstery.  i seriously can't believe i've never had this one before.  Did i say it was lobstery and buttery?  Pricey? Of course... worth it? Hells yes!OH YES... FYI food poisoning does not take affect in less than an hour of eating the food in question.  If anything it was most likely something you ate that morning or afternoon.  So... just a note if you go to a restaurant and get sick within the hour... don't write a review saying said restaurant made you sick.  COME ON PEOPLE!

Reviews.Author: Vincent K.
Reviews.Content: Heidi L. you are my hero.  Good call on this spot as it was one of the local favorites around North End too.  Even though the three of us split only a single lobster roll, 6 oysters, 3 clams, it was good enough to say that this is one of my favorite spots coming to Boston for.  The people were all very friendly, even the lady who waited in line with us was offering all these great suggestions.  Congrats on the 5 year anniversary, and I'll definitely have to come back for a more intense meal instead of trying to fit 3 dinners in one day.   Which reminds of the great contrast with 3 guys sharing one lobster roll vs 3 grown adults next to us each ordering one for themselves....those fatasses.....how I envy them.The MA oysters were delicious, and the lobster roll HOT (with butter) is one of the best I've had (instead of the mayo).

Reviews.Author: Frances G.
Reviews.Content: As evidence from my numerous reviews about my love for oysters, one would think I would review the oyster selection at this Neptune Oyster. On the contrary, my Yelp friends.Although, the oysters are awesome and they give you a huge selection from which to choose the lobster rolls are where it's at! Cold or Hot, their Lobster Rolls are divine. Usually lobster meat can get a little rich, but with the sauce and bread surrounding the lobster your taste buds aren't just experiencing lobster. It's like 'Under the Sea' from Little Mermaid going on in your mouth.

Reviews.Author: Jen S.
Reviews.Content: I met a fellow Yelper here while visiting Boston.  It was great to meet a fellow Bay Area resident so that we could reminisce about our time there.  Now she highly recommended the lobster roll, drenched in butter, stuffed into the most softest roll ever with delish french fries.  Now, the price tag is about $20+ but well worth it for lobster.  The place is small and was packed when we met up at 6pm but got seated promptly at the bar which was a good and bad thing.  Good because we got a seat quickly, bad because for our party of 3, it made conversation pretty awkward.  Service was great and if you do happen to sit at the bar, there is a hook for your purse and jacket underneath.

Reviews.Author: Brett N.
Reviews.Content: Why 5 stars?  Because this was a top 3 meal of my life.   ---   ---   ---I have already claimed an *OFFICIAL* favorite meal of all-time back home in Tampa...but can I make that 1a) and the Hot Lobster Roll 1b) ?I am nearly left speechless after experiencing this mind wrapping paradise.  It's one of those things that tastes so good, it's surreal.  You forget everything going on around you, and realize that you never want your meal to come to an end.First of all, realize that you can only make a reservation in person and not over the phone.  Go put your name on the list and just walk around the North End.  They will call you when your table is ready, it's pretty convenient.  The restaurant is a very small building, and you will likely have to "share" your table with strangers so that they can fit the maximum amount of people in at once.As far as the food goes, until we got to our main entree, everything else we had was good, but not great.  Our oysters did not stand out as anything out of the ordinary.  Our shrimp was the biggest I had ever seen, but tasted no different than what I buy from the grocery store.When it comes to the Lobster Roll, ***DO NOT MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE I DID***Get the hot roll, not the cold one.Again....get the HOT Lobster Roll, not the cold one.One of the biggest regrets of my life, is agreeing with my friend's suggestion of, "Let's order 1 hot, 1 cold and split them."   Man, that was a deathly mistake,Don't get me wrong, the cold roll was good, but the hot roll was a 137 out of 10.  I enjoyed my trip to Boston, but felt that I accomplished everything that I wanted to in just about 2 days.  Fenway was amazing, but now that I have been there I don't necessarily need to go back.  However, I often fantasize about taking a trip all the way to Boston just for another hot lobster roll.

Reviews.Author: Rianne D.
Reviews.Content: Praise the Lord! Neptune Oyster has reinstalled my faith that the east coast can make a fabulous lobster sandwich!Can you hear the angels singing? My previous experience with a lobster roll, from Luke's Lobster in NYC, was such a turn off, I was hesitant to give it another try. Paying $17 for a big bunch of disappointment was like eating crow. But the $25 hot lobster was totally worth it! So were the 2 dozen or so oysters, clam chowder and salad that we ordered.If there's a wait, I love the idea that you can swing by, put your name on a waiting list, leave your cell number, and then wandered away to enjoy the sites or run errands, until Neptune calls you to tell you that your table is ready.

Reviews.Author: Jennie C.
Reviews.Content: Ok. I admit: I'm the kind of person who follows the crowd and just HAVE to try that hot restaurant everybody's talking about. On my 3rd visit to Boston, I finally made it to Neptune. I was rather surprised to be quoted a 30min wait despite going solo. But was called 15min later about an open seat at the bar. Solo dining rules!Ordered 1/2 a dozen oysters and the cioppino.  The oysters were of course so fresh and no broken shells, so I was off to a good start. The cioppino...OMG...makes me want to move to Boston. It was packed with seafood and every single morsel was cooked to perfection: mussels, clams, fish, prawns...you name it. The prawns were so sweet and succulent it almost made me hate living in the Midwest. All of it was paired with a flavorful, spicy broth and toasted bread. I admit I wondered whether it was all hype and hesitated when I saw the prices on the menu. But this place is for real. I'm making this a must-go when I visit Boston again!

Reviews.Author: Jeanne L.
Reviews.Content: Best lobster roll in Boston! I was on a mission to have my first lobster roll in Boston. As a tourist, I heard clam chowder and lobster roll were the must try's. I spent $25 on  the most delicious, warm and buttery lobster roll with was accompanied by a heaping portion of fries.  The roll was huge and each piece of lobster was the size of a shrimp. I barely got to the yummy fries and thoroughly enjoyed my first meal in Boston. The ambiance is cozy and busy. There is a dining area and bar seating. It's on the smaller scale but I was able to grab an open seat at the bar. The staff was attentive and the gentleman to my right, who was a regular mentioned this was the best place to dine in Boston and recommended that I come back for dinner.

Reviews.Author: Laura S.
Reviews.Content: We came here during off peak hours (mid afternoon on Monday) and pretty much had the whole place to ourselves.  The ambiance was cozy and inviting (dark wood paneling, white tiles, nice clean, long, white counter top with bar stools, menu items written on the mirrors on the wall, etc.).  If you haven't figured out by the name, seafood is the main attraction, with the lobster roll being the star of the show.  Since we were going to be having dinner within a few hours, we chose to split a warm lobster roll and the PEI mussels.  I loved Hook & Co's lobster roll but this was absolutely divine.  Remember analogies?  Neptune Oyster is to Hook & Co as Ferrari is to Lexus.  The bread was toasted and buttery, as was the warm lobster meat (it's also available cold with mayo).  This is the real deal.  Mere words can't describe the deliciousness.  Again, just look at the picture.  I know a picture is worth a thousand words, so I'll just let this speak for itself.  yelp.com/biz_photos/y2w6…The mussels were served with a red curry broth, toasted cashews, cilantro, garlic and lime.  The mussels were fresh and the broth was light but packed a lot of flavor.  We asked our server for some bread to dip into the broth so we wouldn't resort to using a spoon.  Trying to keep it classy, you know.  The lobster roll was $25, and the mussels were $14, a bit pricey but delicious.  It was the perfect amount of food for a late lunch.  I would definitely go back.

Reviews.Author: Carlie C.
Reviews.Content: I have to admit...Neptune Oyster lived up to its hype.  I am a fan.  You have to try their decadent $25.00 hot lobster roll doused in butter.  And their selection of oysters was probably some of the best I've ever had.  Top Oyster picks:Peacock CoveWellfleet They also offer a great selection of wines as well to accompany your meal (I liked the white wine from Santorini and Croatia).Be prepared to wait for a table or walk around the North End and get a cannoli before dinner or if you're adventurous enough, try to fit in two dinners like I did: bit.ly/qqdesD

Reviews.Author: Shanna K.
Reviews.Content: ** CAUTION: I GOT FOOD POISONING HERE!*** The BeginningSo I went to Boston for a school interview and was craving to have some great seafood with my mom while I was out in Boston. I saw all the great reviews for Neptune's Oyster and tried the following foods:    a) 3 different types of raw oysters suggested by the waitress    b) fish taco special    c) cioppini    d) some appetizer with grains*** The MiddleFISH TACO's were the best I've every had! It had two different fishes and was cooked perfectly flaky with their special sauce. CIOPPINI was good too, with a healthy amount of seafood. APPETIZER was so so. OYSTERS were okay. I felt great after our meal and was headed off to the airport back to California ... when suddenly (dun dun Dun) ........*** THE end1 hour into my flight I immediately got diarrhea and started to barf (this is all while I was in the middle seat, the guy next to me couldn't even look at me) and I realized I had food poisoning. I didn't eat anything before Neptune's so I knew it had to have been something there. Additionally, me and my mom ordered crab legs, but they said they ran out and we didn't get it, but realized we were still CHARGED for the crab legs. NOTE: I feel that if you're going to serve raw food or seafood in general that it needs to be properly handled, stored, and cooked, which was obviously not done. All I know is that it's not worth it for me to go back and eat here after experiencing 4 days of being ill and throwing up.

Reviews.Author: Ian S.
Reviews.Content: To: The lobster(s) who died a hot and buttery death for my cousin's lobster rollFrom: IanRe: Thank youThank you for your sacrifice. My cousin - who hails from a landlocked Mountain West state and wanted to try a true East Coast specialty - thought you were absolutely delicious. You made the City of Boston proud.# # #Neptune Oyster is the place to go for shellfish. The oyster selection is expansive and well explained. The cherrystone clams were among the largest I have ever seen. The steamed littlenecks were laden garlic and had a smokey, almost porky flavor that I could have eaten forever.I'm less convinced that Neptune is the place to go for fish. My cioppino, while nicely seasoned with a kick, was somewhat unremarkable. The saffron rice was undercooked (I think they meant for the rice to keep cooking in the hot broth after it was brought to the table, but that didn't quite happen). I'm of the opinion that a fisherman's stew should be a messy affair: Neptune's refined interpretation took a little away from the soul of the dish. And there wasn't any lobster. Sadness.Cioppino notwithstanding, the people at Neptune obviously know what they're doing. I'm just happy to find someone else who takes clams and oysters on the half shell as seriously as I do.

Reviews.Author: Eliad C.
Reviews.Content: Had the Sea Bass on cream of eggplant (I recall cream of eggplant, hope I'm not getting too old) and it was very very good. Another member of the party had the Lobster.Can't go wrong with either but they were cooked amazing so it isn't a question of "Playing safe" but just what you fancy from two outstanding dishes.

Reviews.Author: EricaLynn J.
Reviews.Content: 1.6 seconds.What, you ask?  What is 1.6 seconds?Well, silly, that's the amount of time it took for me to be completely, hopelessly, happily in love with Neptune Oyster.   All it took was one oyster.  The next 20 were just as delicious.   And everything else thereafter.

Reviews.Author: Debby L.
Reviews.Content: What I ate:- hot lobster roll with butter [3lbs of lobster in it]- Kumomoto Oysters- Riptide Oysters- Mussels with Foie Gras melted atop and infused with apple- venison and Tuna Tartar Sandwich with cucumber relish- clam chowderWhat i loved: EVERY F***ING THING.The lobster roll is a must. You cannot go here and not get it. I ate the whole thing by myself and I was supposed to share it with my friend. It's $25 and worth every penny.The mussels were insanely good. We got this as appetizer and add on, but I could of had about 5 more lbs of this. I did not expect this to be sooo good. I didn't order it, but i could not stop stealing it from Rhett!The oysters were great [i like the riptide better but others in my party disagree]. They were both fresh and no sand. Soft and chilled to perfection.The venison/tuna sandwich was out of this world, but was insanely large. Share this dish. The venison and tuna are the perfect pair and I never knew. We split it between 4 people and it was a massive dish for only $18. The clam chowder is very interesting. I don't think it was the best I've had in Boston, but it was very good. It had chopped parsley in it, so if you're not a parsley person, avoid this. Dinnertime is insane. We went earlier for late lunch around 3....and it was amazing. No wait. Seated immediately and enjoyed everything without the cramped space.

Reviews.Author: Julie R.
Reviews.Content: After hearing about these hot buttered lobster rolls for years and having never set food in this establishment, I knew where I wanted to have a special lunch. The lobster roll didn't disappoint. It was hearty, buttery, falling out the seams, just delicious. Even the fries on the side were good too. We also added a slew of shellfish, mostly a variety of oysters and then some clams. Again, as awesome as you can get for fresh shellfish. Yellow-fin sashimi was refreshing. It was served spread out on a plate with a avocado and citrus glaze. Neptunes on piggyback, were pork belly served on top of a fried oyster. Mouth watering.This place will cost you, but its worth every penny!The waitstaff can have a tude, which adds to its Boston charm. I'm sure the volume can be overwhelming.  They aim to get the food out quick and get you out the door cause there are always people in line waiting for a table.

Reviews.Author: Azmyra K.
Reviews.Content: Is it really the best lobster roll in town? Is it really as good as the hype? YES!Neptune, besides being a Boston institution, serves some of the freshest and most delicious seafood around. The lobster rolls are simple and done without complication (I'd particularly recommend the hot lobster roll) and the oysters are fresh and briny in the best way. This small restaurant located in the North End probably will require you to wait awhile (think in hours not minutes) but it will leave an impression far in excess of the time you waited.While I expect to live in many new places in the years ahead, in my mind as far as lobster rolls and oysters go, Neptune will be the near impossible standard to which I will judge all others.

Reviews.Author: Angie L.
Reviews.Content: The place is quaint but definitely closeknit.  Small, but accomodated us right away.  Probably better for pairs rather than groups.My friend is an oyster-lover so she says this is oyster heaven for her.  I'm not too big on oyster so I got the lobster roll, which suffice it to say, was definitely PLENTY of lobster - Boston has really great lobster!  But flavorwise, all it is, is really buttery lobster sitting inside of a tender roll (reminiscent of a kings roll in texture)  The gentleman next to me asked me how my roll was, perhaps he wanted a taste?  And when I described it was just OK, he offered me some of his flavorful lobster appetizer which he deemed had more flavor than mine (just from the looks of it)I think if you're an oyster-connoisseur, you should try this place but the lobster roll was a little overhyped for me.

Reviews.Author: Nadine F.
Reviews.Content: This was one of the top ten meals of my life.  I had the clam chowder and a lobster roll with fries.  The clam chowder was good and tasted really fresh.  The fries were good too.  But the lobster roll....oh my god.  It should be illegal for something to be this delicious.It was succulent, warm, fresh lobster, dripping with butter on a perfectly toasted brioche roll.  It was nothing short of amazing.  Everyone should eat a lobster roll at Neptune at least once in their life.  It was pricey at $25, but worth every penny.The service was great, and they have a huge wine list.  I was very happy with my Chardonnay, and it complemented the food really well.  I will definitely be back, and I recommend Neptune to anyone who travels to or near Boston.

Reviews.Author: Christy D.
Reviews.Content: What to say about Neptune Oyster?  This place has over a thousand reviews...mostly bragging about the lobster roll.  Well, I have a different perspective...My friend and I got on the list for the last table for the evening at 8 pm.  We had a 2 hour wait to be seated, which was expected.  It was crazy to see people being turned away for the evening, but I figured it was a good sign.  They take your cell number and call you when your table is ready, which is awesomely convenient.  To me, the wait is not an issue if the food meets expectations.So, our table was ready and we started to dine.  I ordered the toasted lobster roll, hot and buttered.  My friend ordered the curried mussels and the clam chowder.  Maybe it was the fact that we were the last to arrive for the evening, but my lobster roll was very underwhelming.  There were some tender, delicous pieces of lobster, likely from the claws, but a good deal of the meat was chewy and lackluster.  The roll was soggy and untoasted and the butter did nothing to help.  For $26, I would expect more.  I noticed other patrons with soggy rolls left on their plates as well.Now, my friend's dishes, the chowder and mussels, were much tastier.  I absolutely loved the mussels, and our server brought bread to dip in the curried sauce.  Very tasty!  Her chowder was just okay to me, it seemed like a "broth" that was mostly cream and not much else.But there is one most notable character missing from my review and that is...the oysters.  I ordered two Thacher Island oysters based on their description of being plump with a buttery finish.  Talk about amazing!  Those were the best I'd had and very memorable.  They were perfect with a squeeze of lemon.For the price, the wait and the overall meal, I'd say this place ended up being average.  I'd consider going again, early, but for just the mussels and oysters.  However, if you're in Boston for a short time, like myself, I'd recommend checking out Island Creek Oyster Bar instead for their take on mussels and oysters.

Reviews.Author: Angel S.
Reviews.Content: Thank god for citisearch, where my friend, Jeannette, found this gem. Being tourists in Boston, it was semi difficult to avoid the traps like the Old Union Oyster House (I think that's the name), so discovering lesser known, more affordable, and more delicious places is a game Jeannette and I love to play.Located in the North End, Neptune Oyster house is small and a little more hidden than other seafood joints in the area. Once we walked in, a regular exclaimed, "Excellent choice!!" and proceeded to recommend some of his favorites from the seafood bar and menu. We ordered raw oysters, clams, and crab. Jeannette loved the riverrock oyster. The Lobster roll was amazing as were the spicy fried mussels. Whoa, I'm salivating as I type. All I know is that once I move to Boston, I have got to be careful not to make this place a habit -- seafood is pricey! check out more of the menu and fair costs on neptuneoyster.com

Reviews.Author: Michael S.
Reviews.Content: Sometimes my eyes get bigger than my stomach. Triton PlateauFried Oysters on top of braised pork belly on crustiniHamachi tartar on mint kimchi Seared scallops with braised pork blue cheese and chestnutsClam chowder Burger with fired oysters and homemade tarter sauceA few Allagash whites This was quite a lineup for two people. We got through everything but half the burger and half the scallops. The plateau was one of the best I've had. Oysters, clams, mussels, crab salad, lobster cocktail, shrimp cocktail. Shrimp were perfectly done and were some the hugest I've had. Everything else was exceptionally fresh except the crab salad was kinda lame.Fried oysers. Imagine kentucky fries oysters on top of braised pork belly on a toasted piece of baguette some braised yellow raisins and microgreen salad. Holy shit!  Hamachi tartar with mint kimchi was suprisingly good. The kimchi was real kimchi and not some bullshit attempt. It wasn't over powering like I thought it would be. This dish really really worked. Scallops were kinda bland and over powered by the other ingredients. There were way to many things on the plate. Cheese, pork, scallop, pomegranite seeds, greens, chestnuts and more. The scallops were lost. Clam chowder was light and filled with fresh clams. Pretty good, but I kinda like the thick gloppy chowders. The burger was HUGE!  Couldn't really taste the fried oysters but could def feel their added silkiness. Home made tartar sauce was money. A few Allagash whites to wash everything downSPECTACULAR!!!!

Reviews.Author: Lillian C.
Reviews.Content: Food: Awesome oysters! I had a bunch of oysters and they were great- loved that they had a wide selection of local oysters with descriptions of what they might taste like. I personally liked the winter point oysters but the selection might change depending on the season. I also liked the clam chowder because it was less creamy than most chowders, and  more briny and full of clam flavors.Atmosphere: upscale, quaint but small. Tip: Put your name on the list with your phone number and they will call you 1-2 hours later when your table is ready. Expect to wait but it's not so bad if you plan ahead!

Reviews.Author: Will E.
